sense.name: intuitions, a hunch or feeling
sense.examples: In my heart I know she is right. Sally poured her heart out last night to Mary, over dinner. Bob has had a change of heart about the new job in Seattle.

sense.name: a muscular organ that pumps blood through the body
sense.examples: His father was a famous heart surgeon in Houston. They detected a heart murmur in the infant. They have beef heart on the menu. John got his resting heart rate down by doing regular aerobic exercise. The diva put her hand to her heart as the audience gave a standing ovation. (figurative extension)

sense.name: having spunk, courage, enthusiasm
sense.commentary: HEART[+quality][+emotional][+courage] Note: can refer to a temporary outlook or behavior during one event (unlike Sense 6)
sense.examples: The race horse showed great heart and came from behind to win the race by a length. The team was losing heart as the opposing pitcher kept striking them out. The patient took heart from the encouraging news of his latest test results. It takes a lot of heart to keep going after a setback of that magnitude. He has really put his heart into this project.

sense.name: the center or middle of something, the locus
sense.examples: They have an apartment right in the heart of Manhattan. She made a Caesar salad with hearts of romaine lettuce. He was the heart and soul of the Chicago Democratic Party for decades. (at the center of its activities)

sense.name: the essence or gist of something
sense.examples: The negotiators have not really gotten to the heart of this labor dispute. Pete's jealousy of his brother's financial success is really the heart of the family tension. Anne Frank believed that people are really good at heart.

sense.name: temperament or disposition, outlook
sense.commentary: HEART[+quality][+personality][+temperament] Note: refers to an ongoing disposition, not behavior during a single event
sense.examples: Those volunteers all have big hearts. The old pirate had an evil heart. Betty thinks Bob has no heart to disdain the federal programs for the poor. Bob thinks Betty is a bleeding heart liberal. John is finally getting over his broken heart. Mary is the kind of person who wears her heart on her sleeve.

sense.name: a form or figure, a shape
sense.examples: The child drew a big red heart on the envelope. The woman had a small heart tattooed on her shoulder. I got chocolates on Valentine's Day in a box shaped like a heart.

sense.name: affection or fondness for something
sense.examples: The great king won the hearts and minds of the populace. We lost our hearts to the six-week-old yellow lab puppy. The young princess declared she would never give her heart to any man.

sense.name: a playing card in a major suit
sense.examples: Mary held five hearts in her bridge hand. The card I'm holding is either a diamond or a heart. John bid three hearts.

sense.name: by rote, from memory
sense.examples: The actor learned all his lines by heart in three days. She recited the entire poem of the Rime of the Ancient Mariner by heart.

sense.name: with deep concern
sense.examples: You shouldn't take their criticisms to heart so much. He actually took Bob's suggestion to heart and started a company!
